metadata.title: Dyslexia, Deep (Acquired)
anatomical location body part affected: Left hemisphere cortex;(1) cerebral lesions of the left perisylvian region(2)

ICD-10 codes.R48.0: dyslexia and alexia _ (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

Other Speech Language Pathology G-code s.G9174: Other speech language pathology functional limitation, current status at time of initial therapy treatment/episode outset and reporting intervals
Other Speech Language Pathology G-code s.G9175: Other speech language pathology functional limitation, projected goal status at initial therapy treatment/outset and at discharge from therapy
Other Speech Language Pathology G-code s.G9176: Other speech language pathology functional limitation, discharge status at discharge from therapy/end of reporting on limitation

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Acquired deep dyslexia is a reading deficit in which the patient presents with phonological difficulty (e.g., inability to sound out the letters to get the word, inability to read non-words)  as well as semantic errors (e.g., substitution of synonyms, antonyms, or subordinates for the target word).(3) Patients also sometimes exhibit morphological errors (errors in inflection).(4) Reading accuracy is affected by semantic and grammatical features of a word (e.g., concrete, highly imageable nouns [e.g., dog, airplane] are read better than words with low imageability [e.g., with, there]).(5) Writing deficits usually reflect reading deficits. Patients with Broca’s aphasia often have deep dyslexia.(3) For detailed information on assessment and treatment of Broca’s aphasia, see Clinical Review…Aphasia, Broca’ s (Nonfluent Aphasia) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708882 Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Depression and anxiety are common in persons with brain injury and can adversely affect test performance.(11) Speech-language  pathologists (SLPs) should be knowledgeable about symptoms of depression (e.g., loss of interest in daily activities, problems sleeping, feelings of sadness and hopelessness) and refer to a neuropsychologist or clinical psychologist when signs are present.(11) Persons with aphasia or TBI might not be able to complete standardized tests or answer questions regarding medical history. It is recommended that the parent/caregiver/ spouse be involved in all assessment procedures. Tests to assess cognitive ability or premorbid cognitive ability through reading (National Adult Reading Test [NART]) are not valid for persons with acquired dyslexia.(12) Risk for falls is often present in persons with stroke or brain injury

pathogenesis: Deep dyslexia is caused when brain injury prevents blood from reaching the areas of the brain that control reading ability,resulting in damage to brain cells(8)
risk factors stroke: Age (risk of stroke doubles each decade after age 55)(9)
Sex (more common in women than men)(9)
risk factors tbi: Teenagers and young adults, especially those 15 to 24 years of age(10)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document the underlying cause of deep dyslexia (i.e., stroke, TBI, neurological disease). Refer to neurological testing for site and size of lesion

course of treatment.medications: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs). The concurrent use of multiple medications is common among older adults who have complex medical conditions, and the side effects of these medications might adversely affect cognitive and communicative functioning.(11) Contact a pharmacist or physician with questions about side effects(11)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Note the results of any neurological (magnetic resonance imaging [MRI], computerized tomography [CT]), neuropsychological, or psychological/cognitive tests that have been completed
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home training programs or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and their efficacy
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had speech-language  therapy for this or for other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors -Does the patient have vision problems? -Does the patient have more difficulty reading some types of texts (e.g., newspaper, novels, instructions)? -Obtain information about order of acquisition of each language and language history (e.g., language used in education)(12) -Which language is used in different situations (e.g., work, home, with relatives, with friends)?(13) -What modalities are used in each language (e.g., reading, speaking, writing)?(13) -Premorbid proficiency in each language can be compared to present proficiency using a 7-point scale (e.g., 1 = not fluent, 7 = native proficiency)(14) -Does the patient have a mood disorder (e.g., depression) that affects motivation to communicate?(15)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms. Examples include aphasia, depression, reduced/impaired physical mobility, dysphagia, apraxia, overall health status, and vision deficits
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document any respiratory difficulties the patient is experiencing (e.g., use of supplemental oxygen, mechanical ventilator)Depression and anxiety are common in persons with brain injury; inquire about symptoms of depression (e.g., loss of interest in daily activities, problems sleeping, feelings of sadness and hopelessness) and refer to a neuropsychologist or clinical psychologist when symptoms are present(11) -Many depression scales and psychological scales have been used to assess patients who have had stroke. The SLP can collaborate with the psychologist to determine the appropriate evaluation with respect to the patient’s language -Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) (mild aphasia)(15) -Depression Intensity Scale Circles (DISC) (moderate aphasia)(15) -Stroke Aphasic Depression Questionnaire (severe aphasia  to be completed by caregiver)(15) -Visual Analogue Self-Esteem  Scale(16)Note hearing ability -Does the patient have difficulty hearing in the quiet treatment environment? -Does the patient ask for frequent repetitions? -Does the patient have a known hearing loss? If so, does he or she wearing hearing aids? Left, right, or bilateral? -It is appropriate to recommend audiology consult for patients with suspected hearing loss Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document any previous communication difficulties. Document any previous learning disability
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Refer to medical charts and ask patient or patient’s family about other problems, including hearing loss, vision deficits, diabetes, cancer, heart disease, and psychiatric disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in hobbies that involve reading (e.g., book clubs, poetry readings, Toastmasters)? Does the patient work and/or attend school? Does the patient regularly use a computer/telephone?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document if the patient uses any adaptive equipment to communicate (e.g., pen/paper)
social and occupational history.living environment: Document information about the living environment including stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, and the language(s) that the patient uses in the home and community

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Note if patient wears hearing aids or glasses; if hearing aids are used, determine if they are in working order. Note if patient uses any devices to assist with mobility (e.g., walker, wheelchair)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Screening for vision and hearing should always precede screening for reading difficulties. An audiologist should check for impacted cerumen prior to a pure-tone audiometric screening and word recognition testing.(11) Informal assessment of vision is required if patient intends to support communication with visual methods (e.g., writing, gestures, pictures) –In a study conducted in the United Kingdom of 177 patients with reading impairment following a stroke, researchers found that in the majority of patients the reading impairment was related to a visual impairment such as visual field loss, eye movement deficit, or low central vision(31)
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: When selecting tests, clinicians must consider the patient’s level of awareness and cultural and linguistic background.(11) Tests that have normative information on diverse groups should be used when possible.(11) The following are some examples of standardized tests that can be used to assess language, reading,All general tests of aphasia have subtests that assess reading comprehension; however, many language tests have only a few items and are insufficient for detecting milder problems, distinguishing between reading disorders, or(19) To assess different modalities of language (auditory, visual, gestural) and processing functions. Contains subtests for analyzing reading disorders(20) To assess components of language structure such as orthography, phonology, word and picture semantics and morphology, and syntax(21) To assess oral language (verbal fluency, language information content, comprehension, repetition and naming), nonverbal language, and reading and writing. Contains a supplementary task to aid the clinician in distinguishing among surface dyslexia, deep dyslexia, and visual dyslexia -For detailed information on aphasia assessment, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic –Bilingual assessment (as needed)(22) Assesses the bilingual patient’s ability to use each language in different settings by a language use history questionnaire. A computer program is available to evaluate responses in more than 100 different languages -Other assessments have been adapted and standardized for Spanish speakers (e.g., BDAE-3,  WAB-R, PALPA)  -Deep dyslexia might impact one language more than another. For patients who speak transparent languages, such as Italian or Spanish, in which there is a very regular correspondence between phonemes and graphemes (e.g., “a” is almost always pronounced/read as /a/), deep dyslexia may not occur as frequently or with as much severity. For patients who speak opaque languages, such as English, in which there are many more sounds that correspond to each grapheme and/ or combination of letters (e.g., “a” will correspond to different phonemes in the words “save,” “all,” and “car”), deep dyslexia is likely to occur more frequently or with increased severity(6,23,24) –Reading -Reading comprehension(3)(25) Contains single word, sentence, and paragraph comprehension tasks as well as tasks of functional reading of signs and labels -Oral reading of single words, nonwords, sentences, and paragraphs(3) -Other tests designed to assess developmental reading disorders may be appropriate in determining age or grade level equivalencies for individuals with acquired dyslexia; these include the Gates-MacGinitie  Reading Tests, the Woodcock Reading Mastery Tests, and the Nelson-Denny  Reading Test(26,27,28)Some tests that assess communication used in daily living contain(29) Assessment of the following areas of communication Reading, Writing, and Using Numbers; Social Interaction; Divergent Communication; Contextual Communication; Nonverbal Communication; Sequential Relationships; and Humor/Metaphor Absurdity(30) Assessment of functionalsocial communication; communication of basic needs; reading, writing, and number concepts; and daily planningAssess oral and written spelling ability(3)Assess written language(3) -Agraphia/dysgraphia (written language impairment) often co-occurs  in patients with deep dyslexia. For detailedSpeechT708854
relevant tests and measures.oral structure and oral motor function: A motor speech evaluation should be performed if there are signs of coexisting apraxia or dysarthria –For detailed information on assessment and treatment of apraxia, see Clinical Review…Apraxia of Speech (Acquired) ;T708586 –For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysarthria (spastic, flaccid, ataxic, hypokinetic, and hyperkinetic), see the series of Clinical Reviews on these topics
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Refer to psychological and cognitive evaluations to assist in informing course of treatment and providing a prognosis for therapy. Many tests of cognition are reading based, and the patient’s reading skills should be carefully considered before test administration. A comprehensive evaluation for acquired dyslexia should assess visual-perceptual  processes, visual spatial attention, and working memory(3)(17) To assess cognitive status of adults. Sections include Orientation to Time, Orientation to Place, Registration, Attention and Calculation, Recall, Naming, Repetition, Comprehension, Reading, Writing, Drawing(18) To assess intellectual and cognitive abilities of adults

contraindications precautions.general: The relative benefits and risks of intensive therapy should be evaluated on a case-by-case

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The clinical diagnosis of acquired deep dyslexia is made by the SLP by use of standardized reading assessments
assessment plan of care.rule out: Deep dyslexia should be distinguished from other types of dyslexia (e.g., surface dyslexia, phonological dyslexia) and from a visual field deficit, low vision, and visual neglect dyslexia.(5) In both phonological and deep dyslexia, the patient presents with difficulty with the phonological reading route so that pseudowords and functor words are read poorly. Deep dyslexia differs from phonological dyslexia in that the patient makes semantic errors during reading (e.g., “cat” for “dog”).(33) Some researchers believe that deep dyslexia and phonological dyslexia represent points on a continuum, with deep dyslexia as the most severe manifestation of the disorder(24,34,35)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Refer to OT for assistance with daily living skills if needed. Refer to a psychologist or counselor for depression or anxiety. Refer to an eye specialist to rule out visual impairment
treatment summary: Phonologically based approaches –Link-word  technique:  Several studies have examined the effects of a therapy that teaches grapheme-phoneme correspondences using a “link-word” technique.(37) Patients are taught to use their own link word for every letter of the alphabet. For example, one subject used his wife’s name (“Carole”) to link the /k/ sound to the letter “c.” After practice associating the link word with the grapheme, the patient is then taught to produce the initial phoneme alone and then sound out each letter of the word. Results of a study conducted in the United Kingdom indicated that a subject with deep dyslexia was able to learn how to read simple words and to improve oral naming ability by self-cueing  by producing the initial sound of the word.(38) However, this subject and subjects in two other studies had difficulty blending phonemes into syllables and words(3) –Grapheme-to-phoneme  and bigraphs/syllables:  The Wilson Reading System, a reading approach that trains GPC and blending, was trialed in one patient with deep dyslexia.(39) Syllable shapes (consonant-vowel-consonant  [CVC]) were taught in conjunction with individual letter sounds. A multiple-baseline  design using control and treatment probes was used to evaluate treatment effects. The subject was trained only on CVC syllabic structure and was able to reacquire blending skills for CVC words but not for other structures. In addition, there was a reduction in semantic errors. Results suggest that improvement was directly related to treatment but that generalization to untrained syllable structures did not occur(39) –In a study conducted in the United States, researchers examined the effectiveness of a similar bigraph approach (training of CV and VC shapes). Results indicated that two subjects with deep dyslexia were able to blend trained bigraphs to read trained and untrained words. Results did not generalize to untrained bigraphs.(33) Results of a later case study with a patient with Broca’s aphasia and deep dyslexia also indicated that the bigraph approach improved reading accuracy and comprehension. In addition, the approach improved reading of low-imageability words(40) –In a case study involving a 38-year-old  Spanish-speaking female patient with deep dyslexia following resection of a left hemisphere brain tumor, an SLP trained simple CV and CVC and V-only  syllables to improve reading skills(23) -Additional therapy techniques included exercises aimed at increasing phonological awareness, improving word reading, and developing word-semantic correspondences(23) -Following 2 years of therapy for 30 minutes 3 times per week, the patient recovered near-normal  reading skills with improved, but still impaired, reading of nonwords(23)

Semantically based approaches –Lexical priming:  Lexical priming trains the patient to recognize the written form of a word by associating it with its picture. In a case study, a subject with deep dyslexia was presented with an index card with the word written on one side and the picture and the word on the other (10–15  words per session).(2) The SLP read the word and the subject was encouraged to construct a mental association between the word and its image. Between sessions, the subject was required to read the words twice a day. Post-test  and follow-up  sessions indicated that the patient was able to read treatment words more correctly than the control (untreated) words(2)

Instruction for increasing reading fluency and comprehension –Oral Reading for Language in Aphasia (ORLA):  ORLA involves the patient repeatedly reading aloud sentences and short paragraphs, first in unison with the clinician and then independently.(3) The approach is based upon learning principles, including active participation by the learner, repetitive practice, over-learning  of skills, use of meaningful materials, and opportunities for success. Authors of a case study of a patient with deep dyslexia examined the effects of ORLA on oral reading ability. The treatment included a total of 24 one-hour  sessions over 7 weeks. Results indicated the ORLA was effective in improving oral reading of trained sentences, and improvements in reading comprehension were seen in subtests of the WAB and the RCBA-2(3) . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Deep dyslexia Increase understanding of rule-based spelling to assist in word readingGPC _ Provide systematic instruction of GPC rules. Patients practice specific rules to assist them in decoding unfamiliar words (e.g., “c” before “a,” “o” and “u” is pronounced /k/). Effects of this approach are mixed due to difficulties in blending phonemes(30,36) _ _ See Treatment summary , aboveSLP introduces each rule individually and provides opportunities for the patient to practice the new rule; once the rule is mastered at accepted level (generally 80% or higher), another rule will be introduced and practiced until mastery is achievedLearning GPC rules can be practiced at home  Deep dyslexia Increase ability to sound out wordsLink-word technique _ Patient can be taught to use his or her own link word for every letter of the alphabet. For example, a patient can use a friend’s name (e.g., “Ben”) to link the beginning sound (/ b/) to the specific letter “b”(38) _ _ Patient will: 1) associate a link word with each sound, 2) produce the link word after seeing the letter, 3) produce the sound (without the link word) after seeing the letter, 4) blend sounds together to produce simple words(38) _ _ Results of studies have indicated mixed success in blending phonemes(3) _ _ See Treatment summary , aboveAfter practice associating the link word with the grapheme, the patient is then taught to produce the initial phoneme alone and then sound out the word. Another objective may be to increase the patient’s ability to self-cue by writing the word and then producing the initial phoneme (effective for patients with better written than spoken naming skills)(38)Patient can practice sound-word associations at home with assistance  Deep dyslexia Increase ability to sound out words by learning GPC and syllable shapesGrapheme-to- phoneme and bigraphs/syllables _ The Wilson Reading System is an adolescent/adult reading program that focuses on improving the use of GPC through learning bigraphs and syllables, as well as improving blending and phonological awareness using multisensory presentation and hierarchical instruction. This program is distinguished from other GPC programs in that it specifically trains recognition of syllables and syllable shapes. Case studies using a bigraph/ syllable training approach suggest that this approach assists individuals with deep dyslexia in reducing semantic errors in oral reading and improve accuracy of oral reading for the targeted syllable structure(33,39) _ _ See Treatment summary , aboveThe Wilson Program indicates a hierarchy of treatment with specific consonants, vowels, and syllable shapes. The criteria for introduction of new phonemes is 90% accuracy(39)Patient can practice GPC and syllable shapes at home with assistance  Deep dyslexia Increase ability to read specific wordsLexical priming _ Lexical priming trains the patient to recognize the written form of a word by associating it with its picture. The SLP presents the patient with an index card with the word written on one side and the picture and word on the other (10–15 words per session). The SLP reads the word and patient is encouraged to construct a mental association between the word and its image. Between sessions, the patient should practice reading the words twice a day(2) _ _ See Treatment summary , above1. Patient learns to construct a mental image of the printed word by looking at the word and corresponding picture; 2. Patient learns to read the word in treatment sessions; 3. Patient learns to read the words independently at homePatient can practice reading the words independently at home  Deep dyslexia Increase reading fluency and reading comprehension by practicing repeated readings of words, sentences, phrases, or text (newspaper articles)Oral Reading for Language in Aphasia (ORLA) _ ORLA involves a series of steps of repeated reading intended to increase reading fluency and comprehension. A summary of the steps is below: 1.The SLP reads a text aloud to the patient and points to each word as it is read. The length of the material may vary from 3 to 100 words depending on the skills of the

maintenance or prevention: Clinic-based  treatment should eventually be transferred to home-based routines so that the patient and caregivers can continue treatment independently
patient education: Patient and family education should include information on the effects of deep dyslexia, treatment options, and prognosis. When possible, the partner or patient’s family should be educated about facilitative techniques to use when assisting the patient with communication and reading Note

Recent review of the literature has found no updated research evidence on this topic since previous publication on September 30, 2016 Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
